summary: Since 1994, the General Services Administration has commissioned designs for 153 buildings as part of its Design Excellence Program, which encourages the creative design of new buildings for federal agencies. However, we found that GSA doesn't require this program's architects to obtain and consider community input on building designs. Such requirements could help integrate federal buildings into the local community—and reduce local opposition to the...
title: Federal Real Property: GSA Should Include Community Input Requirements to Help Fulfill Design Excellence Program Goals
